column1: Belawan (Chinese: 勿老灣; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: mài lau ôan) is a harbor in Medan
column2: Indonesia. Located on the northeast coast of Sumatra
column3: Belawan is Indonesia's busiest seaport outside of Java. It constitutes the most northerly of the city of Medan's 21 administrative districts (kecamatan)
column4: and covers an area of 29.44 km2; at the 2010 Census it had a population of 95
column5: 506.There are weekly passenger ships operated by Pelni from Medan to Tanjung Balai Karimun

column1: A regular ferry service connects Belawan to across the Strait of Malacca to Penang
column2: Malaysia; at times there was a ferry that also ran from Belawan to Phuket

column1: The port was initially built in 1890
column2: to provide a location where tobacco could be transferred directly between rail lines from the interior and deep-draft ships. The harbor expanded in 1907 with the construction of a new section intended for Chinese and indigenous traders
column3: reserving the existing port for European shipping. In the early twentieth century the port's business expanded
column4: with the growth of major rubber and palm oil plantations in northern Sumatra. In the 1920s several major berthing facilities were built.

column2: the port was the largest port in the Dutch East Indies
column3: in terms of cargo value. Cargo volumes dropped substantially after Indonesian independence
column4: and did not reach pre-independence levels again until the mid-1960s.  A major restructuring in 1985 saw the construction of a container terminal; it almost immediately captured about one-fifth of Indonesia's containerized exports.  Major products exported include rubber
